Emergency & Main Plumbing Valves
The photo above shows a typical main shutoff valve at the curb location. Inside the home, another "main" valve should be installed to allow occupants in emergency situations to fully stop all water from entering the home. Usual locations are above water heaters, in basements, utility closets or crawl spaces.
A sewer cleanout is required for public waste
disposal systems. These are located just as
the sewer pipe exits the building.
(Usually required to be within the first 3 feet)


ALWAYS TURN OFF ELECTRICITY IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK FROM THE BREAKER PANEL

1] If the leak is coming through the ceiling finish, use a screwdriver or other similiar
object to create a hole in the drywall where the water is actively dripping (this will help
minimize water damage to the structure)

2] Place a bucket directly under the hole to catch any water that will drain out

3] Find the shutoff valve that controls water flow to the fixture that is leaking (behind toilet, under sink,
exterior hosebib shutoff, main water shutoff, etc.

4] Call a licensed and insured plumber to complete needed repairs
(Scroll down for emergency leak procedures...)
If you have an active leak from a burst pipe or damaged fixture...

exterior
interior
